'''Acoustic theory''' is a scientific field that relates to the description of [[Sound#Longitudinal_and_transverse_waves|sound waves]]. It derives from [[fluid dynamics]]. See [[acoustics]] for the [[engineering]] approach.
Propagation of sound waves in a fluid (such as water) can be modeled by an equation of continuity (conservation of [[mass]]) and an equation of motion (conservation of [[momentum]]) . With some simplifications, in particular constant density, they can be given as follows: : <math>  egin{align}  rac{\partial p}{\partial t} + \kappa~
abla \cdot \mathbf{u} & = 0 \qquad 	ext{(Mass balance)} \ ho_0  rac{\partial \mathbf{u}}{\partial t} + 
abla p & = 0 \qquad 	ext{(Momentum balance)} \end{align} </math> where <math>p(\mathbf{x}, t)</math> is the acoustic pressure and <math>\mathbf{u}(\mathbf{x}, t)</math> is the [[flow velocity]] vector, <math>\mathbf{x}</math> is the vector of spatial coordinates <math>x, y, z</math>, <math>t</math> is the time, <math>ho_0</math> is the static mass density of the medium and <math>\kappa</math> is the [[bulk modulus]] of the medium. The bulk modulus can be expressed in terms of the density and the speed of sound in the medium (<math>c_0</math>) as : <math>\kappa = ho_0 c_0^2 ~.</math> If the flow velocity field is [[irrotational]], <math>

''Engineering Principles in Acoustics'', Allyn and Bacon Inc., Boston.</ref> :<math> \cfrac{\partial^2 \mathbf{u}}{\partial t^2} - c_0^2~
abla^2\mathbf{u} = 0 \qquad 	ext{or} \qquad \cfrac{\partial^2 p}{\partial t^2} - c_0^2~
abla^2 p = 0, </math> where we have used the [[vector Laplacian]], <math>

abla^2 \varphi = 0 </math> and the momentum balance and mass balance are expressed as :<math> p + ho_0~\cfrac{\partial\varphi}{\partial t} = 0 ~;~~ ho + \cfrac{ho_0}{c_0^2}~\cfrac{\partial\varphi}{\partial t} = 0 ~. </math>
==Derivation of the governing equations== The derivations of the above equations for waves in an acoustic medium are given below.
===Conservation of momentum=== The equations for the [[Derivation of the Navier–Stokes equations#General form of the Navier–Stokes equations|conservation of linear momentum]] for a fluid medium are :<math> ho \left( rac{\partial \mathbf{u}}{\partial t} + \mathbf{u} \cdot 
abla \mathbf{u}ight) = -
abla p + 
abla \cdot oldsymbol{	au} + ho\mathbf{g} </math> where <math>\mathbf{g}</math> is the body force per unit mass, <math>p</math> is the pressure, and <math> oldsymbol{	au}</math> is the [[Cauchy stress tensor#Stress deviator tensor|deviatoric stress]]. If <math> oldsymbol{\sigma}</math> is the [[Cauchy stress tensor|Cauchy stress]], then :<math> p := -	frac{1}{3}~	ext{tr}( oldsymbol{\sigma}) ~;~~  oldsymbol{\sigma} := -p oldsymbol{I} +  oldsymbol{	au} </math> where <math>  oldsymbol{I}</math> is the rank-2 identity tensor.
We make several assumptions to derive the momentum balance equation for an acoustic medium. These assumptions and the resulting forms of the momentum equations are outlined below.
====Assumption 1: Newtonian fluid==== In acoustics, the fluid medium is assumed to be [[Newtonian fluid|Newtonian]]. For a Newtonian fluid, the deviatoric stress tensor is related to the flow velocity by :<math> oldsymbol{	au} = \mu~\left[
abla\mathbf{u} + (
abla\mathbf{u})^Tight] + \lambda~(
abla \cdot \mathbf{u})~ oldsymbol{I} </math> where <math>\mu</math> is the shear [[viscosity]] and <math>\lambda</math> is the [[bulk viscosity]].
Therefore, the divergence of <math> oldsymbol{	au}</math> is given by :<math>  egin{align} 
abla\cdot oldsymbol{	au} \equiv \cfrac{\partial s_{ij}}{\partial x_i} & = \mu \left[\cfrac{\partial}{\partial x_i}\left(\cfrac{\partial u_i}{\partial x_j}+\cfrac{\partial u_j}{\partial x_i}ight)ight] + \lambda~\left[\cfrac{\partial}{\partial x_i}\left(\cfrac{\partial u_k}{\partial x_k}ight)ight]\delta_{ij} \ & = \mu~\cfrac{\partial^2 u_i}{\partial x_i \partial x_j} + \mu~\cfrac{\partial^2 u_j}{\partial x_i\partial x_i} + \lambda~\cfrac{\partial^2 u_k}{\partial x_k\partial x_j} \ & = (\mu + \lambda)~\cfrac{\partial^2 u_i}{\partial x_i \partial x_j} + \mu~\cfrac{\partial^2 u_j}{\partial x_i^2} \ & \equiv (\mu + \lambda)~
abla(
abla\cdot\mathbf{u}) + \mu~
abla^2\mathbf{u} ~. \end{align} </math> Using the identity <math>
abla^2\mathbf{u} = 
abla(
abla\cdot\mathbf{u}) - 
abla	imes
abla	imes\mathbf{u}</math>, we have :<math> 
abla\cdot oldsymbol{	au} = (2\mu + \lambda)~
abla(
abla\cdot\mathbf{u}) - \mu~
abla	imes
abla	imes\mathbf{u}~. </math> The equations for the conservation of momentum may then be written as :<math> ho \left( rac{\partial \mathbf{u}}{\partial t} + \mathbf{u} \cdot 
abla \mathbf{u}ight) = -
abla p + (2\mu + \lambda)~
abla(
abla\cdot\mathbf{u}) - \mu~

abla	imes\mathbf{u} + ho\mathbf{g} </math>
====Assumption 2: Irrotational flow==== For most acoustics problems we assume that the flow is irrotational, that is, the [[vorticity]] is zero. In that case :<math> 
abla	imes\mathbf{u} = 0 </math> and the momentum equation reduces to :<math> ho \left( rac{\partial \mathbf{u}}{\partial t} + \mathbf{u} \cdot 
abla \mathbf{u}ight) = -
abla p + (2\mu + \lambda)~
abla(
abla\cdot\mathbf{u}) + ho\mathbf{g} </math>
====Assumption 3: No body forces==== Another frequently made assumption is that effect of body forces on the fluid medium is negligible. The momentum equation then further simplifies to :<math> ho \left( rac{\partial \mathbf{u}}{\partial t} + \mathbf{u} \cdot 
abla \mathbf{u}ight) = -
abla p + (2\mu + \lambda)~
abla(
abla\cdot\mathbf{u}) </math>
====Assumption 4: No viscous forces==== Additionally, if we assume that there are no viscous forces in the medium (the bulk and shear viscosities are zero), the momentum equation takes the form :<math> ho \left( rac{\partial \mathbf{u}}{\partial t} + \mathbf{u} \cdot 
abla \mathbf{u}ight) = -
abla p </math>
====Assumption 5: Small disturbances==== An important simplifying assumption for acoustic waves is that the amplitude of the disturbance of the field quantities is small. This assumption leads to the linear or small signal acoustic wave equation. Then we can express the variables as the sum of the (time averaged) mean field (<math>\langle\cdotangle</math>) that varies in space and a small fluctuating field (<math>	ilde{\cdot}</math>) that varies in space and time. That is :<math> p = \langle pangle + 	ilde{p} ~;~~ ho = \langlehoangle + 	ilde{ho} ~;~~ \mathbf{u} = \langle\mathbf{u}angle + 	ilde{\mathbf{u}} </math> and :<math> \cfrac{\partial\langle p angle}{\partial t} = 0 ~;~~ \cfrac{\partial\langle ho angle}{\partial t} = 0 ~;~~ \cfrac{\partial\langle \mathbf{u} angle}{\partial t} = \mathbf{0} ~. </math> Then the momentum equation can be expressed as :<math> \left[\langlehoangle+	ilde{ho}ight] \left[ rac{\partial	ilde{\mathbf{u}}}{\partial t} + \left[\langle\mathbf{u}angle+	ilde{\mathbf{u}}ight] \cdot 
abla \left[\langle\mathbf{u}angle+	ilde{\mathbf{u}}ight]ight] = -
abla \left[\langle pangle+	ilde{p}ight] </math> Since the fluctuations are assumed to be small, products of the fluctuation terms can be neglected (to first order) and we have :<math>  egin{align} \langlehoangle~ rac{\partial	ilde{\mathbf{u}}}{\partial t} & + \left[\langlehoangle+	ilde{ho}ight]\left[\langle\mathbf{u}angle\cdot
abla \langle\mathbf{u}angleight]+ \langlehoangle\left[\langle\mathbf{u}angle\cdot
abla	ilde{\mathbf{u}} + 	ilde{\mathbf{u}}\cdot
abla\langle\mathbf{u}angleight] \ & = -
abla \left[\langle pangle+	ilde{p}ight] \end{align} </math>
====Assumption 6: Homogeneous medium==== Next we assume that the medium is homogeneous; in the sense that the time averaged variables <math>\langle p angle</math> and <math>\langle ho angle</math> have zero gradients, i.e., :<math> 
abla\langle p angle = 0 ~;~~ 
abla\langle ho angle = 0 ~. </math> The momentum equation then becomes :<math> \langlehoangle~ rac{\partial	ilde{\mathbf{u}}}{\partial t} + \left[\langlehoangle+	ilde{ho}ight]\left[\langle\mathbf{u}angle\cdot
abla \langle\mathbf{u}angleight]+ \langlehoangle\left[\langle\mathbf{u}angle\cdot
abla	ilde{\mathbf{u}} + 	ilde{\mathbf{u}}\cdot
abla\langle\mathbf{u}angleight] = -
abla	ilde{p} </math>
====Assumption 7: Medium at rest==== At this stage we assume that the medium is at rest, which implies that the mean flow velocity is zero, i.e., <math>\langle\mathbf{u}angle = 0 </math>. Then the balance of momentum reduces to :<math> \langlehoangle~ rac{\partial	ilde{\mathbf{u}}}{\partial t} = -
abla	ilde{p} </math> Dropping the tildes and using <math>ho_0 := \langlehoangle</math>, we get the commonly used form of the acoustic momentum equation :<math> ho_0~ rac{\partial\mathbf{u}}{\partial t} + 
abla p = 0 ~. </math>
===Conservation of mass=== The equation for the [[Derivation of the Navier–Stokes equations#Conservation of mass|conservation of mass]] in a fluid volume (without any mass sources or sinks) is given by :<math> rac{\partial ho}{\partial t} + 
abla \cdot (ho \mathbf{u}) = 0</math> where <math>ho(\mathbf{x},t)</math> is the mass density of the fluid and <math>\mathbf{u}(\mathbf{x},t)</math> is the flow velocity.
The equation for the conservation of mass for an acoustic medium can also be derived in a manner similar to that used for the conservation of momentum.
====Assumption 1: Small disturbances==== From the assumption of small disturbances we have :<math> p = \langle pangle + 	ilde{p} ~;~~ ho = \langlehoangle + 	ilde{ho} ~;~~ \mathbf{u} = \langle\mathbf{u}angle + 	ilde{\mathbf{u}} </math> and :<math> \cfrac{\partial\langle p angle}{\partial t} = 0 ~;~~ \cfrac{\partial\langle ho angle}{\partial t} = 0 ~;~~ \cfrac{\partial\langle \mathbf{u} angle}{\partial t} = \mathbf{0} ~. </math> Then the mass balance equation can be written as :<math>  rac{\partial	ilde{ho}}{\partial t} + \left[\langlehoangle+	ilde{ho}ight]
abla \cdot\left[\langle\mathbf{u}angle+	ilde{\mathbf{u}}ight] + 
abla\left[\langlehoangle+	ilde{ho}ight]\cdot \left[\langle\mathbf{u}angle+	ilde{\mathbf{u}}ight]= 0 </math> If we neglect higher than first order terms in the fluctuations, the mass balance equation becomes :<math>  rac{\partial	ilde{ho}}{\partial t} + \left[\langlehoangle+	ilde{ho}ight]
abla \cdot\langle\mathbf{u}angle+ \langlehoangle
abla\cdot	ilde{\mathbf{u}} + 
abla\left[\langlehoangle+	ilde{ho}ight]\cdot\langle\mathbf{u}angle+ 
abla\langlehoangle\cdot	ilde{\mathbf{u}}= 0 </math>
====Assumption 2: Homogeneous medium==== Next we assume that the medium is homogeneous, i.e., :<math> 
abla\langle ho angle = 0 ~. </math> Then the mass balance equation takes the form :<math>  rac{\partial	ilde{ho}}{\partial t} + \left[\langlehoangle+	ilde{ho}ight]
abla \cdot\langle\mathbf{u}angle+ \langlehoangle
abla\cdot	ilde{\mathbf{u}} + 
abla	ilde{ho}\cdot\langle\mathbf{u}angle = 0 </math>
====Assumption 3: Medium at rest==== At this stage we assume that the medium is at rest, i.e., <math>\langle\mathbf{u}angle = 0 </math>. Then the mass balance equation can be expressed as :<math>  rac{\partial	ilde{ho}}{\partial t} + \langlehoangle
abla\cdot	ilde{\mathbf{u}} = 0 </math>
====Assumption 4: Ideal gas, adiabatic, reversible==== To close the system of equations we need an [[equation of state]] for the pressure. To do that we assume that the medium is an [[ideal gas]] and all acoustic waves compress the medium in an [[adiabatic]] and [[Reversible process (thermodynamics)|reversible]] manner. The equation of state can then be expressed in the form of the differential equation: :<math> \cfrac{dp}{dho} = \cfrac{\gamma~p}{ho} ~;~~ \gamma := \cfrac{c_p}{c_v} ~;~~ c^2 = \cfrac{\gamma~p}{ho} ~. </math> where <math>c_p</math> is the [[specific heat]] at constant pressure, <math>c_v</math> is the [[specific heat]] at constant volume, and <math>c</math> is the wave speed. The value of <math>\gamma</math> is 1.4 if the acoustic medium is air.
For small disturbances :<math> \cfrac{dp}{dho} \approx \cfrac{	ilde{p}}{	ilde{ho}} ~;~~ \cfrac{p}{ho} \approx \cfrac{\langle p angle}{\langle ho angle} ~;~~ c^2 \approx c_0^2 = \cfrac{\gamma~\langle pangle}{\langle ho angle} ~. </math> where <math>c_0</math> is the [[speed of sound]] in the medium.
Therefore, :<math> \cfrac{	ilde{p}}{	ilde{ho}} = \gamma~\cfrac{\langle p angle}{\langle ho angle} = c_0^2 \qquad \implies \qquad \cfrac{\partial	ilde{p}}{\partial t} = c_0^2 \cfrac{\partial	ilde{ho}}{\partial t} </math> The balance of mass can then be written as :<math> \cfrac{1}{c_0^2} rac{\partial	ilde{p}}{\partial t} + \langlehoangle
abla\cdot	ilde{\mathbf{u}} = 0 </math> Dropping the tildes and defining <math>ho_0 := \langlehoangle</math> gives us the commonly used expression for the balance of mass in an acoustic medium: :<math>  rac{\partial p}{\partial t} + ho_0~c_0^2~
abla\cdot\mathbf{u} = 0 ~. </math>
==Governing equations in cylindrical coordinates== If we use a [[cylindrical coordinate system]] <math>(r,	heta,z)</math> with [[basis vectors]] <math>\mathbf{e}_r, \mathbf{e}_	heta, \mathbf{e}_z</math>, then the [[gradient]] of <math>p</math> and the [[divergence]] of <math>\mathbf{u}</math> are given by :<math>  egin{align} 
abla p & = \cfrac{\partial p}{\partial r}~\mathbf{e}_r + \cfrac{1}{r}~\cfrac{\partial p}{\partial 	heta}~\mathbf{e}_	heta + \cfrac{\partial p}{\partial z}~\mathbf{e}_z \ 
abla\cdot\mathbf{u} & = \cfrac{\partial u_r}{\partial r} + \cfrac{1}{r}\left(\cfrac{\partial u_	heta}{\partial 	heta} + u_right) + \cfrac{\partial u_z}{\partial z} \end{align} </math> where the [[flow velocity]] has been expressed as <math>\mathbf{u} = u_r~\mathbf{e}_r+u_	heta~\mathbf{e}_	heta+u_z~\mathbf{e}_z</math>.
The equations for the [[conservation of momentum]] may then be written as :<math> ho_0~\left[\cfrac{\partial u_r}{\partial t}~\mathbf{e}_r+\cfrac{\partial u_	heta}{\partial t}~\mathbf{e}_	heta+\cfrac{\partial u_z}{\partial t}~\mathbf{e}_zight] + \cfrac{\partial p}{\partial r}~\mathbf{e}_r + \cfrac{1}{r}~\cfrac{\partial p}{\partial 	heta}~\mathbf{e}_	heta + \cfrac{\partial p}{\partial z}~\mathbf{e}_z = 0 </math> In terms of components, these three equations for the [[conservation of momentum]] in [[cylindrical coordinates]] are :<math> ho_0~\cfrac{\partial u_r}{\partial t} + \cfrac{\partial p}{\partial r} = 0 ~;~~ ho_0~\cfrac{\partial u_	heta}{\partial t} + \cfrac{1}{r}~\cfrac{\partial p}{\partial 	heta} = 0 ~;~~ ho_0~\cfrac{\partial u_z}{\partial t} + \cfrac{\partial p}{\partial z} = 0 ~. </math>
The equation for the [[conservation of mass]] can similarly be written in [[cylindrical coordinates]] as :<math> \cfrac{\partial p}{\partial t} + \kappa\left[\cfrac{\partial u_r}{\partial r} + \cfrac{1}{r}\left(\cfrac{\partial u_	heta}{\partial 	heta} + u_right) + \cfrac{\partial u_z}{\partial z}ight] = 0 ~. </math>
===Time harmonic acoustic equations in cylindrical coordinates=== The acoustic equations for the [[conservation of momentum]] and the [[conservation of mass]] are often expressed in time [[harmonic]] form (at fixed [[frequency]]). In that case, the pressures and the flow velocity are assumed to be time harmonic functions of the form :<math> p(\mathbf{x}, t) = \hat{p}(\mathbf{x})~e^{-i\omega t} ~;~~ \mathbf{u}(\mathbf{x}, t) = \hat{\mathbf{u}}(\mathbf{x})~e^{-i\omega t} ~;~~ i := \sqrt{-1} </math> where <math>\omega</math> is the frequency. Substitution of these expressions into the governing equations in [[cylindrical coordinates]] gives us the fixed frequency form of the [[conservation of momentum]] :<math> \cfrac{\partial\hat{p}}{\partial r} = i\omega~ho_0~\hat{u}_r ~;~~ \cfrac{1}{r}~\cfrac{\partial\hat{p}}{\partial 	heta} = i\omega~ho_0~\hat{u}_	heta ~;~~ \cfrac{\partial\hat{p}}{\partial z} = i\omega~ho_0~\hat{u}_z </math> and the fixed frequency form of the [[conservation of mass]] :<math> \cfrac{i\omega \hat{p}}{\kappa} = \cfrac{\partial \hat{u}_r}{\partial r} + \cfrac{1}{r}\left(\cfrac{\partial \hat{u}_	heta}{\partial 	heta} + \hat{u}_right) + \cfrac{\partial \hat{u}_z}{\partial z} ~. </math>
====Special case: No z-dependence==== In the special case where the field quantities are independent of the z-coordinate we can eliminate <math>u_r, u_	heta</math> to get :<math>  rac{\partial^2 p}{\partial r^2} +  rac{1}{r} rac{\partial p}{\partial r} +  rac{1}{r^2}~ rac{\partial^2 p}{\partial	heta^2} +  rac{\omega^2ho_0}{\kappa}~p = 0 </math> Assuming that the solution of this equation can be written as :<math> p(r,	heta) = R(r)~Q(	heta) </math> we can write the partial differential equation as :<math> \cfrac{r^2}{R}~\cfrac{d^2R}{dr^2} + \cfrac{r}{R}~\cfrac{dR}{dr} + \cfrac{r^2\omega^2ho_0}{\kappa} = -\cfrac{1}{Q}~\cfrac{d^2Q}{d	heta^2} </math> The left hand side is not a function of <math>	heta</math> while the right hand side is not a function of <math>r</math>. Hence, :<math> r^2~\cfrac{d^2R}{dr^2} + r~\cfrac{dR}{dr} + \cfrac{r^2\omega^2ho_0}{\kappa}~R = \alpha^2~R ~;~~ \cfrac{d^2Q}{d	heta^2} = -\alpha^2~Q </math> where <math>\alpha^2</math> is a constant. Using the substitution :<math> 	ilde{r} \leftarrow \left(\omega\sqrt{\cfrac{ho_0}{\kappa}}ight) r = k~r </math> we have :<math> 	ilde{r}^2~\cfrac{d^2R}{d	ilde{r}^2} + 	ilde{r}~\cfrac{dR}{d	ilde{r}} + (	ilde{r}^2-\alpha^2)~R = 0 ~;~~ \cfrac{d^2Q}{d	heta^2} = -\alpha^2~Q </math> The equation on the left is the [[Bessel equation]], which has the general solution :<math> R(r) = A_\alpha~J_\alpha(k~r) + B_\alpha~J_{-\alpha}(k~r) </math> where <math>J_\alpha</math> is the cylindrical [[Bessel function]] of the first kind and <math>A_\alpha, B_\alpha</math> are undetermined constants. The equation on the right has the general solution :<math> Q(	heta) = C_\alpha~e^{i\alpha	heta} + D_\alpha~e^{-i\alpha	heta} </math> where <math>C_\alpha,D_\alpha</math> are undetermined constants. Then the solution of the acoustic wave equation is :<math> p(r,	heta) = \left[A_\alpha~J_\alpha(k~r) + B_\alpha~J_{-\alpha}(k~r)ight]\left(C_\alpha~e^{i\alpha	heta} + D_\alpha~e^{-i\alpha	heta}ight) </math> Boundary conditions are needed at this stage to determine <math>\alpha</math> and the other undetermined constants.
